data.text: If there’s one takeaway, it’s this: What matters most in platform governance is how decisions get made. You can armchair quarterback specific choices and mistakes all day. But the real work is figuring out how to make principled decisions when all you have are bad options.

urls.title: ‎On with Kara Swisher: Why Twitter’s Former Safety Chief Left Elon Musk on Apple Podcasts
urls.description: ‎Show On with Kara Swisher, Ep Why Twitter’s Former Safety Chief Left Elon Musk - Dec 1, 2022

urls.title: Why Twitter’s Former Safety Chief Left Elon Musk
urls.description: Listen to this episode from On with Kara Swisher on Spotify. Elon Musk's Twitter is a spectacle, and the drama and meaning of the last six months is perhaps best unpacked by Yoel Roth. The company’s former head of trust and safety survived the early flood of firings and resignations — in fact, he was ascendant, in the early days of this new Twitter, and he became the face Musk presented to advertisers. Kara asks Roth whether he felt “used” by Musk and why — having been embraced by Elon’s inner circle — he ultimately decided to abandon Elon.  Before the interview, Kara and Nayeema weigh in on Elon Musk’s seeming needling of Tim Cook, and they discuss whether Apple has too much power. Stay tuned until the end for Kara’s rant on this very topic. You can find Kara and Nayeema on Twitter @karaswisher and @nayeema. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

data.text:
Grateful for the chance to sit down with @karaswisher and talk about the last few years in Trust & Safety at Twitter, warts and all. 

The headlines only scratch the surface of the conversation. 

Apple Podcasts: https://t.co/kDFtUNeuZI
Spotify: https://t.co/gRxGNJVJRG

@EmilyGorcenski Hi Emily - I stopped engaging because I don’t think I can say anything to help here. My long-deleted LiveJournal entries from 2008 don’t represent who I am today, what my beliefs are today, or what I work towards every day. I’m deeply sorry.
@EmilyGorcenski It isn’t.

@EmilyGorcenski Ok. I’m pretty steeped in queer history, and my recollection is different. But I apologize if those tweets caused hurt for you or anyone else; that was not my intent. I don’t think I’m the enemy here.

@EmilyGorcenski The acceptability of that term has changed a lot since I posted those tweets a decade ago. I wouldn’t use that word now. While at Twitter, I did everything within my power to fight to protect folks, including trans people. The work is never done and I wish I could have done more.

urls.title: Silicon Valley's Sex Censorship Harms Everyone
urls.description: The post-FOSTA internet often silences sex workers, queer users, and artists, furthering puritanical ideas about sexuality.

data.text: @jilliancyork I linked to one of your pieces in an original draft (https://t.co/hVWrlToeHv) - ended up not making it into the final version, unfortunately. Your book is a big inspiration and does a much better and deeper job with a lot of the influences here than I could in an op-ed.

urls.title: Opinion | I Was the Head of Trust and Safety at Twitter. This Is What Could Become of It.
urls.description: Elon Musk’s brand of radical transformation has unavoidable limits.

data.text:
Last week, I made the decision to leave my role leading Trust & Safety at Twitter.

Today, I'm sharing a few thoughts about what comes next for the site. https://t.co/QPAQR6zpqU
@timothyjgraham @elonmusk I assume the source for this is public API data? If so, it's worth noting that much of what we're doing re: restricting reach is not reflected in the APIs (at the moment).

Those steps take away many of the gratifications of the trolling here. Bans are frustrating and take work (and resources) to try to circumvent; visibility filtering deprives trolls of the attention and reach they're trying to get.
@mgoldstein Important point! I'll try to share a breakdown that gets into this more specifically soon. Obviously that surface matters too; just not parsed out in this graph.

Update on our efforts to combat hateful conduct: We've not only mitigated the recent surge in harmful behavior, but have reduced impressions on this content in Search by ~95% relative to even prior baseline levels. We're continuing our work to make Twitter safer every day. https://t.co/lK5fMRWCGb https://t.co/g4X6ue0f8W
@GoAngelo I wouldn't agree with that characterization of what I said. More proportionate enforcement for less severe harms doesn't mean reducing the amount of moderation we do.

urls.title: The Twitter Moderation Research Consortium is now open to researchers
urls.description: Starting today, we’re offering researchers around the world the opportunity to apply for membership in the TMRC.

urls.title: Twitter data for academic research
urls.description: From social science to computer science, advance your academic research objectives with public conversation data available through Twitter APIs.

data.text: @JasonAbbruzzese This is our vision with the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (https://t.co/V8cQWO4gR3) — and we already offer leading access, including free access for academics, to all public tweets via our developer APIs (https://t.co/D4qVrSj0WG).

@pwnallthethings Got it - I wasn’t clear you meant compromise after Blue badging. Agree. There’s a longer discussion to have about our historical reluctance to automatically lock down notable accounts when we detect suspicious logins; that’s likely less of a concern for Blue Verification.

@pwnallthethings This assumes we have no post-verification checks or investigations. Sure, it’s a threat vector. It’s also a mitigable one that imposes durable costs on the adversary when caught and shut down. Costs I estimate are higher than the existing buy-a-hacked-blue-check situation.

@pwnallthethings Not sure I agree. It’s not just $8 (in the initial implementation): it’s $8, and a valid credit card that doesn’t have fraud flags, and an Apple ID that doesn’t have any fraud flags, and an iOS device…

@pwnallthethings IMO, it’s and, not or. You’re obviously right that account takeover is a major vector for a whole host of bad things. We need to invest there, and are. But we can also broadly raise the costs of spam that actually reaches people via perceived-credible accounts.
@nicoleperlroth Yep. Or, yknow, all accounts. Google does a great job nudging people towards MFA.

@RMac18 They're still under development. Not trying to evade; just don't want to tell you a bunch of stuff we end up moving away from. Our teams are actively doing threat ideation work to build a broad set of defenses.
@RMac18 That's not the only safeguard we're planning to implement. But this was already an extremely long thread, so...
No solution to identity is perfect, and we’re iterating quickly to come up with the best approach here. We appreciate all the feedback, and will share more as our work progresses.

It’s not just the $8, though — this kind of in-app purchase requires bad actors to get through not only Twitter’s defenses, but also those of mobile device manufacturers and payment processors. That’s not impossible for a sophisticated adversary — but it’s hard to do at scale.

Proof-of-humanness is more straightforward. Most spam-fighting is a numbers game: Your objective is to raise the costs on spammers until their losses exceed their gains. When you do that, the spammers go away, and you win. $8 per account raises the costs of spam A LOT.

For years, Verification on Twitter has been tricky because it’s a signal both of authenticity (you are who you say you are) and notability (you’re “important” by some standard). 

Notability is inherently difficult to determine in a fair way globally. I support getting rid of it.

Long-term, I think we need to invest more in identity verification as a complement to proof-of-humanness. Paid Verification is a strong (not perfect) signal of humanness, which helps fight bots and spam. But that’s not the same thing as identity verification.

We’re particularly focused on the risks of impersonation of public officials in the context of the US 2022 midterm elections, and have made the decision not to launch Verification for Twitter Blue until after Election Day.

In the short term, we’ll ramp up proactive review of Blue Verified accounts that show signs of impersonating another user. When we find them, we’ll suspend them. See something that looks off? You can report it directly in the app.
The planned changes to Twitter Blue to make Verification more widely available raise the stakes for this kind of impersonation. Here’s what we’re going to do about it:

When Verified accounts use impersonation as a tactic — whether for parody or not — it creates an especially confusing experience. It’s been our long-standing practice to suspend Verified users when they do this.

urls.title: Parody, commentary, and fan account policy
urls.description: Learn our requirements for parody, commentary, and fan accounts and how we respond to reports about them.

data.text: Parody has long been recognized as an important form of speech, and we have clear, long-standing guidelines about how to operate parody accounts on Twitter in a non-misleading way: https://t.co/A2lHpnPX31

First, impersonation has always been banned on Twitter. Misleading profiles make Twitter worse for everyone. Last year, we banned more than half a million accounts for impersonating people and brands. https://t.co/rc8ejsISTS
Verification! Impersonation! Twitter Blue! There’s a lot going on around identity on Twitter — let’s break down what our policies are, and some of the big questions we still need to answer…
@MikeIsaac @lrozen @darth Agree. A human reviewer would not designate that tweet abusive or a violation of our rules. We use a higher-recall ML approach in this context to automate. It's not perfect.

urls.title: How Twitter is nudging users to have healthier conversations
urls.description: You can’t ban mean, but you can help build an online environment that promotes, encourages, and supports ways that people can treat each other with more respect.

data.text: @darth @lrozen We've had this for a while, and found it can meaningfully reduce toxicity and abuse. It can also be overzealous sometimes, though. More on our blog: https://t.co/gW8khpDqxB https://t.co/HjQ37yHAMZ
@rebeccamkern No.
@sivavaid We’ll check what’s going on.
@Esqueer_ I don’t want to be remembered for anything. I’m here for the same reason I have been for the last 7.5 years: doing whatever I can to make Twitter better.
@HeidiBriones Update on our child safety work coming soon. This remains a key focus area. We have zero tolerance for CSE.
@EricaJoy @MikeIsaac We haven’t done that. We’re actually expanding how we enforce those rules in the next few days.
@druwynings Those workflows rely on a different toolset than our core moderation actions.

@thehowie Maintaining human moderation isn't the full story; a core part of our approach is deploying tech to detect and take action proactively and automatically. That was the primary driver of what I wrote about in past threads re: hateful conduct.
Recruiters: My DMs are open — I have recommendations for incredibly smart and compassionate talent that is now available.

I’ll continue to share updates about our Trust & Safety work as things evolve in the days to come. Our team's mission of enforcing our policies and protecting the conversations happening on Twitter remains unchanged.

What AREN’T we doing? In the short term, we’ve had to deprioritize a few workflows — like account access (lost password requests), and some suspension appeals. We’re working to get these back online in the days to come.

With early voting underway in the US, our efforts on election integrity — including harmful misinformation that can suppress the vote and combatting state-backed information operations  — remain a top priority.

More than 80% of our incoming content moderation volume was completely unaffected by this access change. The daily volume of moderation actions we take stayed steady through this period. https://t.co/rSGKtq0e3J

Last week, for security reasons, we restricted access to our internal tools for some users, including some members of my team. Most of the 2,000+ content moderators working on front-line review were not impacted, and access will be fully restored in the coming days.

Yesterday’s reduction in force affected approximately 15% of our Trust & Safety organization (as opposed to approximately 50% cuts company-wide), with our front-line moderation staff experiencing the least impact.

Here are the facts about where Twitter’s Trust & Safety and moderation capacity stands today:

tl;dr: While we said goodbye to incredibly talented friends and colleagues yesterday, our core moderation capabilities remain in place.
Tweeps: My DMs are always open to you. Tell me how I can help. 🖤 #OneTeam

urls.title: Twitter’s new reporting process centers on a human-first design
urls.description: Twitter is using insights from researchers, therapists, and writers to test a new way to report everything from misinformation & spam to harassment & hate speech.

data.text: @Jason @Rob1Ham It’s a tough balance. We’ve tried different approaches over the years. Our latest reporting flow prioritizes getting context, because it helps us understand harm and take action more effectively. But the feedback that it’s a little lengthy is well-taken. https://t.co/91l9ONesqK
@DanLinden just setting up my twttrcontactcenter

We're hearing reports of phishing emails talking about potential changes to Verification. Be wary — nothing has launched yet, and we aren't sending these notes. Check the sender carefully, and don't provide your credentials or payment info. https://t.co/eCpXOZM3rn
RT @elonmusk: @yoyoel Talked to civil society leaders @JGreenblattADL, @YaelEisenstat, @rashadrobinson, @JGo4Justice, @normanlschen, @Derri…
We’re staying vigilant against attempts to manipulate conversations about the 2022 US midterms. Read on for independent analysis of our teams’ work 👇 https://t.co/O2MFNqCTY2
@SEP It’s been such a privilege getting to work with you. Thank you. 💙
@jamisonfoser The graph isn’t normalized for impressions per user. Fewer people use the latest home timeline overall.
@DocDre @Sarah_Oestreich Agree. This is what we’re working on fixing. The burden can’t be on the victims of abuse.

This is exactly what we (or any company) should be doing in the midst of a corporate transition to reduce opportunities for insider risk. We’re still enforcing our rules at scale. https://t.co/CZudS4gBqo

@chrismessina I’ve always liked Instagram’s “block other accounts from this person” feature — it’s a smart way to scale content controls.

We know people on Twitter use multiple accounts for lots of different reasons. So you need to be careful about overly restricting that.

@DocDre Struggled with keeping things tweet-length on this one. Essentially, for bystanders, we have to look for multiple signals of abusive intent. If you're first-person reporting, we know you're experiencing it as abuse and don't like what's happening to you in the interaction.

urls.title: The Real Name Fallacy - Coral by Vox Media
urls.description: The Coral Project is an open source project to help publishers of all sizes build better communities around their journalism. We’re creating tools that help everyone to feel safe, respected, and heard.

data.text: @chrismessina Probably not by itself. There's lots of research that suggests confirmed, real-name identity isn't the answer to online abuse (https://t.co/7yDYfxLiJO). But making it harder for bad actors to spin up new accounts can certainly help.

@daveyalba Nothing in my thread disputes the problem — I call it a surge in my first tweet. We have to fix this. This includes removing content, and *also* reducing its visibility at scale. Impressions have been our success measure for a long time.
@tomcoates That tweet is more than a decade old. If you need to know, it was the actual name of a Lord of the Rings-themed drag show I was at. It's not a word I'd use today.

We’re changing how we enforce these policies, but not the policies themselves, to address the gaps here.

You’ll hear more from me and our teams in the days to come as we make progress. Talk is cheap; expect the data that proves we’re making meaningful improvements.

Why? Because bystanders don’t always have full context, we have a higher bar for bystander reports in order to find a violation. As a result, many reports of Tweets that in fact do violate our policies end up marked as non-violative on first review.

To try to understand the context behind potentially harmful Tweets, we treat first-person and bystander reports differently.

First person: This hateful interaction is happening to or targeting me.

Bystander: This is happening to someone else.
Many of you have said you’ve reported hateful conduct and received notices saying it’s not a violation. Here’s why, and what we’re doing to fix it:

Impressions don’t tell the whole story. These issues aren’t new, and the people targeted by hateful conduct aren’t numbers or data points. We’re going to continue investing in policy and technology to make things better.

Impressions on this content typically are extremely low, platform-wide. We’re primarily dealing with a focused, short-term trolling campaign. The 1500 accounts we removed don’t correspond with 1500 people; many are repeat bad actors. https://t.co/qoMFLZJYrA

Our primary success measure for content moderation is impressions: how many times harmful content is seen by our users. The changes we’ve made have almost entirely eliminated impressions on this content in search and elsewhere across Twitter. https://t.co/AnJuIu2CT6

Since Saturday, we’ve been focused on addressing the surge in hateful conduct on Twitter. We’ve made measurable progress, removing more than 1500 accounts and reducing impressions on this content to nearly zero. Here’s the latest on our work, and what’s next.

Elon Musk's Twitter is a spectacle, and the drama and meaning of the last six months is perhaps best unpacked by Yoel Roth. The company’s former head of trust and safety survived the early flood of firings and resignations — in fact, he was ascendant, in the early days of this new Twitter, and he became the face Musk presented to advertisers. Kara asks Roth whether he felt “used” by Musk and why — having been embraced by Elon’s inner circle — he ultimately decided to abandon Elon.  Before the interview, Kara and Nayeema weigh in on Elon Musk’s seeming needling of Tim Cook, and they discuss whether Apple has too much power. Stay tuned until the end for Kara’s rant on this very topic. You can find Kara and Nayeema on Twitter @karaswisher and @nayeema. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

tweets.text:
Grateful for the chance to sit down with @karaswisher and talk about the last few years in Trust & Safety at Twitter, warts and all. 

The headlines only scratch the surface of the conversation. 

Apple Podcasts: https://t.co/kDFtUNeuZI
Spotify: https://t.co/gRxGNJVJRG
gotta say though, this is literally the thesis of my book. https://t.co/aohhiWzd2x
Definite ‘mitigated’ — there’s pretty solid evidence hate speech is at the least constant, and likely on the increase since @elonmusk became CEO https://t.co/WwI2q2OQhX https://t.co/ST2ZmKwZr3
@yoyoel how?

I question how valid of a measurement "impressions in Search" is for hate speech, considering I can't imagine people go searching for slurs. It is the bombardment of hate speech in replies and as a form of targeted harassment that continues to be an issue for users/advertisers. https://t.co/iI8vLoyWNJ

Since Saturday, we’ve been focused on addressing the surge in hateful conduct on Twitter. We’ve made measurable progress, removing more than 1500 accounts and reducing impressions on this content to nearly zero. Here’s the latest on our work, and what’s next.

9/ Musk kicks it over to @yoyoel, who is Twitter's head of trust and safety. Yoel seems to announce that Twitter will be doing *less* moderation in future. And instead will be utilizing not yet revealed tactics to help reduce the harm of certain content.

There ya have it.

@yoyoel I get it, the billing means you can pass cases of actual fraud out to law-enforcement who will have a billing address to chase. But the number of $8 accounts with checks available to be hacked will be far larger than before, and they won't go thru billing and verification steps

@yoyoel Making hacking harder increases the cost in the (a) path, but the (b) path went from something so implausibly labor intensive that I'm not aware of any examples of it into a "throw small change at it" problem.

@yoyoel I'm glad you're working on making account takeovers harder. 

But let's be real, the "cost" for someone to create a dedicated account with a credibility marker from scratch just to spam was previously substantially more than $8 of work to them, and that cost goes *down* now.
This is objectively bullshit. https://t.co/VAFt2iMtEL
@yoyoel Consider MFA by default for verified accounts.
@yoyoel happy to hear about the others if you want to say what they are here
If I’m reading this correctly, Twitter is only going to proactively review if a paid Twitter Blue “verified” account is being a bad actor *after* they do the bad act. https://t.co/w6Vn2pO7NP

It’s not just the $8, though — this kind of in-app purchase requires bad actors to get through not only Twitter’s defenses, but also those of mobile device manufacturers and payment processors. That’s not impossible for a sophisticated adversary — but it’s hard to do at scale.

Proof-of-humanness is more straightforward. Most spam-fighting is a numbers game: Your objective is to raise the costs on spammers until their losses exceed their gains. When you do that, the spammers go away, and you win. $8 per account raises the costs of spam A LOT.

For years, Verification on Twitter has been tricky because it’s a signal both of authenticity (you are who you say you are) and notability (you’re “important” by some standard). 

Notability is inherently difficult to determine in a fair way globally. I support getting rid of it.

Long-term, I think we need to invest more in identity verification as a complement to proof-of-humanness. Paid Verification is a strong (not perfect) signal of humanness, which helps fight bots and spam. But that’s not the same thing as identity verification.

We’re particularly focused on the risks of impersonation of public officials in the context of the US 2022 midterm elections, and have made the decision not to launch Verification for Twitter Blue until after Election Day.

In the short term, we’ll ramp up proactive review of Blue Verified accounts that show signs of impersonating another user. When we find them, we’ll suspend them. See something that looks off? You can report it directly in the app.
The planned changes to Twitter Blue to make Verification more widely available raise the stakes for this kind of impersonation. Here’s what we’re going to do about it:

When Verified accounts use impersonation as a tactic — whether for parody or not — it creates an especially confusing experience. It’s been our long-standing practice to suspend Verified users when they do this.

urls.description: Learn our requirements for parody, commentary, and fan accounts and how we respond to reports about them.

tweets.text: Parody has long been recognized as an important form of speech, and we have clear, long-standing guidelines about how to operate parody accounts on Twitter in a non-misleading way: https://t.co/A2lHpnPX31

First, impersonation has always been banned on Twitter. Misleading profiles make Twitter worse for everyone. Last year, we banned more than half a million accounts for impersonating people and brands. https://t.co/rc8ejsISTS

@lrozen @darth @yoyoel speculating but i think this is a machine learning issue — really more of an example of the limits of AI vs human-centric curation of what is and isnt appropriate

to your point, the context matters

We're still in the early days of seeing how nudges, labels, prompts, and other non-punitive actions can shape online behavior (and yes, sometimes the nudges are meme-worthily bad) — but these are exciting and promising findings. Congratulations to the team that worked on this! https://t.co/0rIaMIy8Aq

.@yoyoel does this mean that you're no longer enforcing your rules against misinformation related to civil integrity, Covid-19, crisis misinformation related to Ukraine or other misinformation related policies anymore? https://t.co/X0x3y1EADm
@yoyoel Is this what you want to be remembered for? Being Elon's flak and telling blatant lies about the moderation on here? It's never worth how ever much he's paying you.
@yoyoel Cool story now tell us why there is still child exploitation material on the platform and what you intent to do about it.

@yoyoel Is it not reasonable to expect that demand for content moderation INCREASED during the days during and after the acquisition closed; and that *steady* moderation represents a failure to keep up?

I’ll continue to share updates about our Trust & Safety work as things evolve in the days to come. Our team's mission of enforcing our policies and protecting the conversations happening on Twitter remains unchanged.

What AREN’T we doing? In the short term, we’ve had to deprioritize a few workflows — like account access (lost password requests), and some suspension appeals. We’re working to get these back online in the days to come.

With early voting underway in the US, our efforts on election integrity — including harmful misinformation that can suppress the vote and combatting state-backed information operations  — remain a top priority.

More than 80% of our incoming content moderation volume was completely unaffected by this access change. The daily volume of moderation actions we take stayed steady through this period. https://t.co/rSGKtq0e3J

Last week, for security reasons, we restricted access to our internal tools for some users, including some members of my team. Most of the 2,000+ content moderators working on front-line review were not impacted, and access will be fully restored in the coming days.

Yesterday’s reduction in force affected approximately 15% of our Trust & Safety organization (as opposed to approximately 50% cuts company-wide), with our front-line moderation staff experiencing the least impact.

Here are the facts about where Twitter’s Trust & Safety and moderation capacity stands today:

tl;dr: While we said goodbye to incredibly talented friends and colleagues yesterday, our core moderation capabilities remain in place.

@Rob1Ham As a user, I agree with this, but the extra friction of explaining the reasons you're reporting seems to be a huge win for the safety team. 

@yoyoel have we explained this to the community? Seems like a great discussion for folks to have.

@yoyoel Talked to civil society leaders @JGreenblattADL, @YaelEisenstat, @rashadrobinson, @JGo4Justice, @normanlschen, @DerrickNAACP, @TheBushCenter Ken Hersch & @SindyBenavides about how Twitter will continue to combat hate & harassment & enforce its election integrity policies

urls.title: Assessing Inauthentic Networks Commenting on the US Midterms — Election Integrity Partnership
urls.description: An assessment of five inauthentic networks on Twitter reveals techniques used by foreign actors targeting domestic US political discourse in the leadup to the 2022 midterm elections. The networks within the dataset were taken down under Twitter’s Platform Manipulation and Spam Policy. In this post,

tweets.text: Happy one week before Midterms! Here's a report we just put out on 6 networks that Twitter released to  outside researchers. 5 of the 6 had a fair bit to say ab American politics, incl the election; they varied bt fake-Dem & fake-Republican perspectives. https://t.co/jrI5SSOaSw
Love and gratitude to everyone.
@Sarah_Oestreich @yoyoel Right

NEW: A wide swath of Twitter's trust & safety team had access to content moderation/enforcement tools frozen last week. Usually, hundreds of people on the team could remove posts w/misinfo, hate speech etc. It's now down to 15 people. Scoop w/@KurtWagner8 @daveyalba @EdLudlow

urls.title: Updates to How We Protect People on Instagram From Abuse | Meta
urls.description: We're updating how we encourage people to be respectful to others on Instagram.

i appreciate the honesty here, but the explanation doesn't really make sense.

@masnick a little help? https://t.co/gpV9Lpeb51

@yoyoel Do you dispute that there has been a surge in hate speech and misinfo on the platform? Is # of impressions the metric you evaluate your success by, not the actual toxic content that's spreading on Twitter?
